div.p: 1. IV. Monday.

The morning was splendid and the canopy of heaven bespangled with its numberless gems in the clearest sky of the Western Hemisphere— I sought for the Planet Mercury, announced in Dick’s celestial scenery to be visible as morning Star about this time, and thought I had found him; but it was one of the minor stars of Leo, that I mistook for him— I saw the Sun rise from the South East corner of Charles’s House, and marked the progress of his Southern declination— I received a Letter from Mr Lay, a member of the 23d. and 24th. Congress from the State of New-York— It was written at Boston last Saturday, and announced his intention to pay us a visit with Mrs Lay, this day— About half an hour afterwards they came, having extended their excursion thus far from Batavia their home, which they left to place two Sons at Yale College in New-Haven— Mr Lay is one of the most amiable men, with whom I ever served in public life, and invariably friendly to me while in Congress.— He had a curiosity to see my fathers Library and my own, which I accordingly shewed him— And he went with me to my Son’s house,—I introduced them to each other— Mr and Mrs Lay, are to leave Boston to return home, to morrow— Louisa C. Smith, with Mary, and Mrs Charles went to Boston, and returned to dine— In the interval, Mrs Lunt, and her Sister Miss Hedge, of Plymouth, visited here— A Quaker by the name of Hartshorn, came and repaired our Clock— He hesitated, whether to receive any pay for the work, saying that he was an Abolitionist, and felt under obligations to me for my service in Congress, especially at the last Session— He consented however to take a dollar— Towards Evening Charles took me to ride with him the round of Milton, and Dorchester. Mr Peter Whitney and his Son Frederick Augustus, who is preaching at Sharon, spent with us a part of the Evening.— There was in the afternoon, a meeting of the Stockholders of the Quincy Stone Bank, to choose Directors, and a Meeting in the Evening of the Association for preserving Gardens and Orchards from depredations, both of which I neglected to attend—though my garden as well as those of my neighbours has been unmercifully robbed, of Peaches, Pears and Apples.
2. IV:15. Tuesday
Boston— Page and Portrait— Quincy.

The morning was again exquisitely fine, and the day, warm as Summer without its languor— I saw most distinctly and unequivocally the Planet Mercury at 5 O’Clock, in a perpendicular direction about ten degrees immediately under
Venus— She was then about 20 minutes risen, and Mercury not more than ten— There was already a bright dawn, and within 20 minutes after and as much before Sunrise, Mercury had vanished though Venus was yet visible— The imperial Astronomer Schubert at St. Petersburg, told me that he believed Mercury was never visible with the naked eye, and this I have no doubt is true in that nebulous Northern Latitude I have seen him now with certainty both as evening and morning Star— I went with Charles to Boston and gave the fourth sitting of three hours to Mr Page for my Portrait— Charles came in while he was at work, but did not like it— He thinks it fails not in the likeness of the features, but in the expression. Dr Parkman was also there and thought well of it— I left the Painter’s Room at one, and went to the Office of the Life and Trust insurance Company where Mr Joseph Tilden has taken the place of the late Dr Bowditch as Actuary— I gave notice as the Trustees for Mrs Abby S. Angier, my Niece, that she wished the annual interest of her annuity at that Institution to accumulate, until further order. She had requested this in a Letter received from her yesterday, and I saw the entry made upon the book— She states that she had made the same request of me last year, but it had escaped my recollection, and Mr Angier had received the interest of the last year this morning— I had met him with the tenant of my Southernmost of the two Houses at the bottom of the Mall, at Charles’s Office— On coming out from the Life insurance Office I met Mr Degrand who took me into Topliff’s reading room—but I had not time to stay there to read. At Foster’s stable, where Charles keeps his horse, I met a somewhat intimate acquaintance of the last century Francis Amory, whom I recognized before he recognized me— He remembered that the last time we had met was at his Sister Mrs M’Lane’s marriage with William Lee— Seven years have passed since that day, during which Mrs Lee herself, and other numerous assemblage of family relations have passed from this world to that of Spirits.— Frank said that he was now the only survivor of six brothers with all of whom I was well acquainted— Of the four Sisters two are yet living. Mrs Lowell and Mrs Bethune— The two others Mrs Codman and Mrs Lee have departed— Mr Amory finally recognized me with great cordiality—promised to visit me, and invited me to visit him at his house in Milton— We got home to dine at half past 2—and spent the Evening at a tea-party at Charles’s— Mr and Mrs Edward Miller, Mr Beale and his daughter Anne, Mr and Mrs Lunt with her Sister Miss Hedge, Harriet Welsh, Elizabeth C. Adams, and Julia De Wint were there— Charles’s son John was apparently recovering— We made one partie quarrée at Whist— Home before ten.
3. IV:30. Wednesday

The sky was partially beclouded so that although I caught a glimpse at Venus, Mercury was not to be seen.— The Sun rose clear but the day was beclouded, with a shower about noon, and a bright Moonlight evening. I went into Boston with Charles and his wife— Fifth sitting of
of about two hours to Mr Page, who will yet want at least two more— But the next is not to be till Tuesday.— Dr Parkman came in just as I was leaving the room, and approved the work so far as it is finished. I paid a visit to my old friend Joseph Hall, now in the 78th. year of his age— Feeble in body and mind— He resigned more than a year since his Office as judge of Probate— I asked him how he amused the passing hours— He said he had occasionally visited the late chief-justice Parsons after he had resigned his seat upon the bench; and always found him reading Novels— And he himself had been lately reading Shakespear He had a Volume of Johnson and Steevens’s edition on his table— His eldest son is Cashier of a Bank in Boston— The youngest, now on a visit here; but settled in the State of Illinois— He invited me to dine with him; but I was engaged with Charles, and Abby at Dr Frothingham’s— Immediately before dinner he baptized the infant Son of Mr Gorham Brooks; already fourteen months old; by the name of Shepherd which was the maiden name of the mother.— The Parents were both there—The grandfather Mr Peter C. Brooks—His Sons Edward and Peter C—the latter with his wife—Governor Edward Everett and his wife and Charles and Abby— Mrs Edward Brooks, a Boott, is in bad health and was not there— Mr and Mrs Sidney Brooks, a Dehon, are in New-York.— Peter C. jr. and Sidney have no children— I enquired of Dr Frothingham his opinion of Townsend’s Historical and Chronological Bible, re edited and published in this Country by Dr T. W. Coit, but he had never heard of it— He told me he was reading Cicero—and we had some conversation respecting the Editions, Translations and commentaries on the great Roman Orator, Philosopher and Statesman— I advised the Doctor to read Ernesti’s Dedication of his Cicero to Christian Ludwig Stigliz the most admirable treatise upon the uses of classical literature that ever was composed— We left the Doctor’s soon after 5. and reached home at the dusk of Evening— Harriet Welsh, and Julia de Wint had dined with our family, but had returned to Charles’s house.
4. III:40 Thursday.

As the Clock struck five this morning I saw the Planets Venus and Mercury, in conjunction; Mercury being about two thirds of a Sun’s disk below and Northward of Venus— Three quarters of an hour later Mercury was barely perceptible and five minutes after could not be traced by my naked eye— Venus being for ten minutes longer visible— I ascertained therefore that in the clear sky of this Latitude, Mercury at his greatest elongation from the Sun, may be seen by a very imperfect naked eye, in the morning twilight for the space of one hour.— He never ranges beyond twilight bounds.— I observed also the rapidity of his movements by the diminished distance between him and Venus since the day before yesterday— Harriet Welsh and Julia De Wint called here this morning and took the Stage for Boston; with Elizabeth C. Adams, who is going to stay till Saturday with her Sister Mrs Angier, at Medford— Julia De Wint is to return next week to Fishkill landing— The pass’d Midshipsman Joseph H was here afterwards from the Navy-yard at Charlestown and
and is to stay with his mother till Elizabeth returns. The Ohio, is to sail about the last of next week. Charles and his wife dined with us— A Mr Bailey from Scituate was here this afternoon, with Mrs Wade of Roxbury, widow of a Revolutionary Officer, falling short of a Pension claim, because married in June 1794. The act of the last Session of Congress extending the Pension grant only to those married before the 1st. of January of that year— She wishes to petition for the extension of the act, to include her case— I told her that if she would have the petition prepared, stating the service of her husband, and the time of her marriage with vouchers and send it to me here any time before the 10th. of next Month, or afterwards before the first Monday in December, by Mail to Washington— I would present it to the House the first petition day of the Session— I paid a morning visit to Mr John Greenleaf, who keeps his chamber, with a paralytic right side, blind and hard of hearing, but cheerful and composed, and still at 75 enjoying life— Returned by a walk over the hills where I found all the stone quarries upon my land deserted— Charles and his wife dined with us; and after dinner I rode with him to Hough’s Neck— On our return, I went and saw the Sun set from his porch at 5:50— They were blasting rocks in the adjoining lot— They spent the Evening here, and we had a whist party— I wrote to Doctor Frothingham, and packed up the four volumes of the Abbé Mongault’s Edition and Translation of Cicero’s Epistles to Atticus, to send him by Charles to-morrow morning— I rectified my mistakes of the conversation with him yesterday.
5. IV:30. Friday

I saw Venus and Mercury this morning; in closer affinity than yesterday, with not more than one third of a Sun’s disk of apparent interval between them; but there was a gathering cloud came and passed over them, which intercepted the continuance of observation— Charles went to Boston, and returned to dine— I wasted the morning in little more than packing documents.— At Noon I went to the Stone temple where the Bell-ringer brought the key, and I copied the Inscriptions on the Monument, of my father and mother— After dinner I visited my garden, with the intention of planting seeds, stones and acorns, but was twice called away—first to Mr James H. Foster and his daughter Mary who paid us an afternoon visit; and then to Mr John Tyler Bigelow, the Secretary of the Boston Lyceum, who came to urge me again to deliver the introductory Lecture to their course—charged as he said by the Directors of that Institution to state the embarrassment of the circumstances in which they stand; having upon what they conceived encouragement from me, given to Mr George Bancroft, given public notice that the Lecture would be delivered by me, and sold 800 tickets on the strength of that notice: and it being now so late that they would find it difficult to supply my place— I assured him that I deeply regretted the necessity I had been under of declining to perform this service. And still more that I was obliged to say, that the public notice in the newspapers
newspapers that I should deliver this Lecture, had not only preceded the visit of Mr Bancroft with the two Mr Smith’s, but was given without my consent or previous knowledge; and when I had actually declined to deliver the Lecture— That since Mr Bancroft was here I had experienced a new failure of my voice, and should be utterly unable this very evening to deliver a long discourse before a numerous assembly; as he might himself perceive by the sound of my voice in a private room— I added that I had received more than 20. applications of the same kind; several of them in consequence, of the public notice that I should deliver the Lecture at the Lyceum, and had been obliged to give the same answer to them all. After which if I should now undertake to speak in one place; all the other applicants would have the right to consider themselves slighted by me— Mr Bigelow said he would report my answer to the Directors, who he had no doubt would be sensible of its reasonableness and would trouble me with no further application— He said the notification in the newspapers had not been given by the Directors, or with their knowledge— The Printer’s boy was here with the proof in the Quincy Patriot of half the list of Anti-Slavery and Anti-Texas Petitioners at the special Session of Congress, which I corrected and returned to him— Mr E Price Greenleaf was here in the Evening.
6. V:15. Saturday.

I was belated after a restless and almost sleepless night, and found Venus and Mercury cheek by jowl, the apparent distance between them not more than an inch, about half an hour risen, with a brightening dawn— The Sun rose 18 minutes past 6. I had lost sight of Venus a quarter of an hour, and of Mercury half an hour before— From 45 to 50 minutes then before Sunrise, I suppose to be then, the longest time during which at his greatest elongation from the Sun, Mercury can be visible to my naked eye in the morning.— To a keener vision I suppose he may be visible a full hour— I doubt if to any one more.— I read this morning Ralph Waldo Emersons Address to the Senior Class of the Students at the Divinity School at Cambridge— He seems ambitious of becoming the founder of a sect, and thinks there is an urgent necessity for a new revelation— I read also in the Newspapers two letters from James Hamilton of South-Carolina, concerning an extraordinary correspondence between Andrew Stevenson, Minister Plenipotentiary of the United States at London, and Daniel O’Connell, the Irish Orator and Patriot— O’Connell at a Public Meeting at Birmingham, to celebrate the emancipation of Slaves in the British West India Colonies, in a violent attack upon the People of the United States, for Slave holding, said he had reason to believe that the Minister of this Country in England, was himself a breeder of Slaves for sale— And said it was infamous— Stevenson wrote to O’Connell, enquiring whether the Report of his Speech in the Newspapers was correct— O’Connell answered that it was not. Stevenson replied that considering this as a disavowal of the offensive part of the Speech, he was satisfied— Upon which James Hamilton wrote a Letter to Ritchie the Editor of the Richmond Enquirer, full of the most
most scurrilous abuse of O’Connell, with a pledge that he will fix the lie upon his brass for denying that the report of his speech was correct— Since this, Hamilton has returned to this Country, in the Great Western, and published in a New-York paper, a second Letter, apologetical of the first— He still promises to prove O’Connell a liar, for denying that the report of his Speech was correct. Fruits of Slavery— I began a Letter in answer to one from Mr Forsyth, the Secretary of State, asking on the part of the President, advice with regard to the application of the funds of the Smithsonian bequest, for his recommendation to Congress— I have long delayed this Letter, and shall now write it with a heavy heart, and a fearful misgiving that this excellent donation will be degraded into a pack of electioneering jobs— This afternoon I planted promiscuously in the seedling beds of my grand children, Mary Louisa, Georgiana Frances, and Louisa Catherine, Apple seeds and Pear Cores, Peach Stones, English white-Oak Acorns, and Shagbark Walnuts, from the old garden tree, which bears this year very thinly. Dr. Duggan was here this Evening with Mr Rand a member of the united Quincy, and Milton Lyceum, who hold their Meetings near the Railway Stone-Meeting, to request me to deliver a Lecture before them— The introductory Lecture would suit them best— I declined for the same reason that I have assigned elsewhere— Charles and his wife spent the Evening here.
7. IV:30. Sunday.

Heavy rain this morning intercepted my view of the two planets now in conjunction— Communion day— Mr Peter Whitney preached the morning Sermon from Revelation 2.10— [“]Be thou faithful unto death, and I will give thee a crown of life.”— A dissertation upon the unspeakable joys of Heaven, in which he quoted all the passages in the new testament, which speak of them as unutterable, and even beyond the reach of human conception— The Style in which they are always spoken of in the Scriptures— Mr Whitney specified conjecturally a multiplication of the senses, inlets to enjoyment, as flies are said to possess a multitude of eyes—but this similitude was not his— Mr Whitney and Mr Lunt administered jointly the communion, of which I partook, praying forgiveness to my enemies, and for peace with all mankind: After dinner Mr Joseph Angier preached from Luke 10.42—“but one thing is needful”—namely religion— A Discourse very well written, and well argued; but it was observed that this was an easy text to descant upon. The superficial arguments for the necessity of religion to the happiness of men, are abundant— The deeper seated ones, are not scanty— But what is religion? Belief in the existence of a God? of the immortality of the Soul? of responsibility to an offended creator? Of the History of Jesus Christ and his Apostles? and finally of the doctrines and precepts of his gospel. All this must be included in the idea of Religion to constitute the happiness of man. Mr Whitney gave notice, that from this time forward the bell for the morning service would be rung at half past 10, and that of the afternoon at a quarter before two— I read the tenth Sermon of the 11th. volume of Saurin; upon the prayer of Jesus Christ for his executioners; [“]father forgive them, for they know not what they do”— Forgiveness of injuries; an inexhaustible theme for a Christian preacher— Saurin starts a question whether prayer was proper for beings so wicked as those; and leaves it not very satisfactorily solved
solved: especially as he quoted the text which says there is a sin for which the apostle says he does not enjoyn upon the disciples to pray. Mr Angier with Charles and his wife spent the Evening with us; discussing the merits of Mr R. W. Emerson’s crazy address and Oration— Clear and cold—
8. IV. Monday

About a quarter before 5. I went over to Charles’s house, with a view to see the rising of the two planets, but before reaching the House, I found them already nearly a quarter of an hour risen: but I could very imperfectly observe them, owing to a succession of black clouds continually intercepting them from my view— The Sun rose 21 minutes after 6— The morning was so cold that I had much difficulty in reading or writing in my chamber; but I finished a Letter begun yesterday in answer to one from the Secretary of State, Forsyth, on the disposal of the proceeds of the Smithsonian bequest— My time for planting is come, but is so much abridged by more pressing concerns that I cannot pursue the object with persevering system. I filled Potwith fresh earth and planted in it a bergamot Pear Core—with sundry Office Apple-seeds, and one, English white Oak-Acorn— Charles went to Boston, and returned home to dine— Just before dinner I went up to the Quincy Stone Bank and cashed a check— After dinner, the weather though clear was so cold that I shrunk from the intended task of planting to which I had devoted it.— Mr. E. Price Greenleaf came and spent it with me in my chamber— Charles and his wife spent the Evening with us— My sore throat and hoarseness with a turn of irressistible drowsiness return upon me every evening, and with the dimness of vision, growing from night to night, disqualify me alike for reading, writing and conversation— I am a nuisance in company, to others, and in solitude to myself.
9. IV. Tuesday—
Boston— Sixth sitting to Page— Quincy.

The sky crystal clear— I went to Charles’ House, and saw the rising of the two planets.— Venus at 4:52, and Mercury two minutes after: both with the proverbial brightness of Morning Stars— As they rose I continued to observe them, till as nearly as I was able to note the disappearance of Mercury in the broadness of the dawn, it was exactly one hour from his rising; or at 5.54. Venus was still visible 20 minutes later; and the Sun rose at 6:23.— This continued observation absorbed the hours and I could only commence a second Letter to the Secretary of State— My benumbed fingers and shivering sides left my diary to run in arrear. I went to Boston with Charles— Called upon Mr George Bancroft now the Collector of the Customs at Boston, and stated to him the cause of my finally declining to deliver the introductory Lecture before the Boston Lyceum. I also mentioned to him the Letters that I am now writing to the Secretary of State concerning the disposal of the Smithsonian bequest, and particularly, my urgent recommendation of the erection and permanent establishment of an Astronomical Observatory.— He promised me not only to write to the President in favour of this project, but to go to Washington, and urge it upon him in person— He sent for his wife and introduced her to me, and repeated a request heretofore made, for the perusal of my mother’s correspondence, of which he wishes to avail himself in the History of the United States, upon which he is engaged, and two volumes of which have already
already been published—eminently successful— I next called on Mr Stott the Seal-engraver who engraved my acorn-seal, and left it with him, to sink a little deeper the Letters of the motto ALTERI SECULO, which are so slightly done, that the impression upon the wax does not take them off legible— I dropped into the Post-Office my Letter to the Secretary of State; and this made it half past ten before I got to the Room of Mr Page the Painter— Gave him a sitting of two hours—the Sixth— This was the number for which I had engaged, but he now says he wants two more. I agreed therefore to give them on Friday and Saturday next— While I was there Isaac P. Davis and Dr Parkman came in; and MrsChapman, who brought, and delivered to me a Letter from Mrs Lydia Maria Child, dated Northampton 15. August 1838. and with an Address from the Anti-Slavey Convention of American women, held at Philadelphia in May last to the Senators and Representatives of the Free States, in the Congress of the Free States— At 1. O’Clock I went to Charles’s Office, and found there Mr Nathaniel Curtis, who gave me a Letter from Jacob W. Watson, Benjamin Harrington, and John Brook a Committee of the Inhabitants of the town of Princeton, proposing to us as Executors of the Will of Ward Nicholas Boylston, proposing a bill in equity to ascertain and determine the property of certain Lands in Princeton, of which he made a donation to its inhabitants— As his Executors and Trustees we make no claim or pretension to the Lands, and Mr Curtis thinks we ought not to be charged with any part of thr expense of ascertaining to whom the lands belong, and he requested me to prepare an answer to that effect— I promised to meet him again at Charles’s office at 1. P.M next Saturday. Call at Frobisher’s shop where the Spoons were ready, but the box was not to my taste— We came home to dinner—another chilling ride, with a clear sky— After dinner I planted promiscuously in my Grandson Charles Francis junrs. seedling Nursery bed. Office and Trowbridge Appleseeds, Pear Cores, Shagbark Walnuts and English white Oak Acorns, and in Potfilled with fresh Earth the Core of a brown bury Pear, given me by Isaac P. Davis and sundry Trowbridge Apple-seeds— But I was soon called away to a visit from the Revd. Mr Lunt, succeeded, by Mr Moody, a yankee from the State of Maine, transplanted to Mobile Alabama, with his bride Georgianna Adelaide, daughter of Mrs Adelaide, widow of Walter Hellen; born in June, I think 1818—they have been married since we left Washington, and are making short excursions before returning to Mobile— They took tea, but declined passing the night here— Mr Beale and his daughter Ann spent also part of the Evening here— Charles and his wife did not come— Mary had dined with them— I was thoroughly chilled, benumbed and somnolent with a sore throat, and a voice so hoarse that I could scarcely speak
10. IV:15 Wednesday

Cloudy morning. No observation of the Planets I have delayed having a fire made in my library, till my fingers refuse their office, and this morning I made the first— I kept my chamber nearly the whole day, and yet found time for nothing but this Diary, and a few lines added to my Letter to Mr Forsyth.— I had no other interruption
interruption than Alpheus Spear, who came and paid his quarters Rent, and for this and the last two years parish tax, which the Assessors exact from me, and which by his lease he is bound to pay— He lost last week an infant Son, eighteen months old, whom he had named John Murray; from the founder of the Universalist sect, to which Alpheus has joined himself.— He was the principal mover to the building of the Universalist Meeting house in this town—one of five new Churches erected in this immediate neighbourhood; chiefly by defections from the first Congregational Church— The first was the Stone Railway Church in Milton; just beyond the borders of Quincy.— Next, this universalist church— Then the orthodox, or Calvinistic church, of which Mr Cornell is the Pastor; and within the last year, two—One, Methodist, at Bent’s point; and one Baptist, in Dorchester, at the Neponset village, just beyond the bridge— The Episcopal church has also been rebuilt, within the same time.— None of these churches have ministers permanently settled, or who remain so— They have preaching with tolerable regularity at them all— Before dinner, I went and made a deposit at the Stone-bank; and at 7. in the Evening went to the Town-Hall, expecting to hear the introductory Lecture to the course of the Quincy Lyceum, by Alexander H. Everett— But the doors of the Hall were closed, and there was no Meeting— Weather stormy.
11. IV:15. Thursday.

Heavy rain this morning till after Sunrise— No observation of the stars— No plantation— After breakfast I visited my Nursery— Gathered a handful of English Oak Acorns, and three Baldwin Apples from the only tree from Medford planted in 1830. which as yet bears more than two or three— And the tree itself is the least grown of them all— I finished my second Letter to Mr Forsyth— Then went to the stone Meeting-house, and from the Bell-ringer named Hall obtained the Key. Mr Page whom I had invited to dine here, came about two— I rode with him to the Meeting House, into which we went, and I shewed him the tablet, surmounted by the Bust of my father executed by Greenough, and the Epitaphs of my father and mother, written by me.— We returned to dine— Charles and his wife dined with us.— Mr Page took with him the engraved print of the stone temple, which I keep suspended in my Library. He wishes to paint in the back-ground of my Portrait a distant view of the Stone Temple— He left us shortly after dinner to return to Boston, and thence to Brookline where he lodges— Mr Alexander H. Everett, and Mr William Foster came and took tea with us— Mr George Newcomb soon after came in and at 7. O’Clock I went with them to the town-Hall, where Mr Everett delivered before the Quincy Lyceum, the introductory Lecture to their course. He announced it, as on the life and character of General Joseph Warren, of which however he said but little— Most of the discourse was a descriptive narration of
of the Battle of Bunker’s Hill, and the burning of Charlestown on the 17th. of June 1775—contained in a printed Oration which he delivered last year at Charlestown, and which he now repeated from Memory. This faculty he and his brother Edward possess in a most enviable degree— But like others, they are proportionally deficient in judgment— Alexander, much more so than Edward—who is by no means deficient in address— The incidents in Warren’s life, related in this Lecture were new to me, and formed part of another Lecture which Everett delivered last winter before the historical Society last Winter in Boston— The delivery of the whole occupied about two hours, during the whole of which the attention of the crowded auditory was constant and intense— The President of the Lyceum George Newcomb then requested the Secretary Jonathan French, my last year’s gardener, to read the minutes of the proceedings of the last Meeting— This was done— Two debateable questions about Phrenology, and the Florida War, laid on the table at the last Meeting, were by vote continued there now— The meeting was regularly dissolved, and the President Newcomb asked Mr Everett what was to pay— The answer I did not hear, but they went apart, and settled it together— At least half the auditory were women— This practice of paying for Lyceum Lectures, and selling tickets of admission to them is becoming common—and the Newspapers state that one of these Institutions in Boston have engaged to give 2500 dollars to the English traveller J. S. Buckingham, to deliver before them his course of Lectures on Egypt and Palestine which we heard him deliver last Spring at Washington— Mr Everett took me home, in his carriage, and then returned with Mr Foster to Roxbury, and the latter to Boston—
12. IV:10. Friday.
Boston. Page. 7th. sitting. Quincy

Clear and Cloudy Morning— I went to Charles’s house to see the planets rise; but a thick haze at the border of the Eastern horizon intercepted them till they were about five minutes risen: afterwards I saw them both repeatedly, but with continual interruption from flitting clouds, till they were lost in the morning dawn. Mercury was returning towards the Sun; about two Sun’s disks below Venus Northwardly, but directly under her about the same distance was another Star, which I suppose to be Spica Virginis, but which I had not before observed— I went to Boston with Charles— Called at Mr Bancroft’s— He was not at home, but I saw Mrs Bancroft, and left with her the four Volumes of Graham’s History of the United States, which he had lent me; and a Volume of the Congressional Documents containing my Report on the Smithsonian bequest, which I requested her to shew him, and say that I would call upon him again to-morrow Morning.— Twice at Stott the engraver’s.— The first time he was not there— The second he said he had been sick, and had done nothing to my Seal; but would have it ready on Monday— Seventh sitting to Mr Page. Dr Parkman came in about noon; and told us a humorous anecdote, about the marriage of the late Dr Freeman, who married a widow Clark— About a fortnight after her marriage to Freeman, she came to breakfast in deep mourning, and upon her
her husband’s enquiring who it was for, she answered, it was for Mr Clark. Dr Parkman, made some application of the moral of this anecdote to Dr Kirkland and Dr Follen, whose wives are Cabots, and exercise as he thinks controuling influence over their husbands.— I called at Mr Bond’s shop; and made some enquiry about his plan of the royal observatory at Greenwich— He said it was at Cambridge— He said Pearson’s practical Astronomy contained an account of all the principal observatories; and of all the instruments, necessary for such an Establishment; and he thought he could borrow the book for me— I told him I would call for it tomorrow— I returned with Charles to Quincy—before dinner— After dinner filled Potwith fresh earth and planted 1 fresh horse-plum-stone; one English white Oak Acorn—the seeds of a brown bury pear and of two Trowbridge Apples.— Planted also in the Seminary seedling bed of Charles’s infant son Henry Brooks a central shagbark walnut in the drupe. Two others and two English Oak Acorns in a diamond square around it; and a circular row of Office Apple-seeds, Peach stones and acorns, round the border of the bed.— Also two Acorns, two Walnuts and two Peach-stones; crosswise in the Seminary Alley, at the Eastern end— Kirk has uprooted my red and black oaks and my stake button-wood, opposite Old Hickory, to transpant them into Charles’s grounds— This afternoon by my direction he sawed off the lowest four limbs of the tree, which branched out so low as to obstruct the passage through the alley— The clouds were gathering the whole day— Towards the dusk of Evening it began to sprinkle and settled into a steady rain, all the Evening— Mr Lunt was here this morning, with another Gentleman while I was gone.
13. III:45. Saturday.
Boston— Page— Dinner at Abbott Lawrence’s Quincy.

I went to Charles’s house to observe the rising of the Planets—but was disappointed. The Atmosphere above the horizon was clear— The moon at her 27th. day—Orion—the Great and little dog were brilliant and the eastern border of the horizon illuminated by the moon, was to the eye apparently as clear as the Zenith— But I waited a quarter of an hour after the time of Venus’s rising; and she was not to be seen— I returned home; and a quarter of an hour after, saw her emerging from a greasy cloud, which as the dawn brightened darkened over the South-eastern horizon— Thickening, transient nebulous vapours, continually flitted over her face, and she appeared like the revolving light at the entrance of Boston Harbour beneath her— I saw not Mercury at all—but Charles who at 4. O’Clock had gone upon the wharf to fish for Smelts did see him— I went to Boston in the Carriage alone— Called at Mr Bancrofts and returned the Volumes of Graham’s History which he had lent me. Gave him my Eulogy on James Monroe; my Letters to Stone and Livingston on Masonry; my Minority Report on Manufactures in Feby 1833— My Report to the Overseers of Harvard University in August 1834, and my Oration at Newbury-Port in July 1837— He asked for the Eulogy on Madison, of which I have no spare copy here; but promised to send him one from Washington— I gave him also the Congressional Document of Commerce and Navigation for 1837. and Randolph’s Report of Commerce and Navigation on
on the cultivation of the Mulberry and Sugar Beet— I read to him my second Letter to the Secretary of State on the disposal of the Smithsonian funds; and left with him the Report of C. F. Mercer to the H.R.U.S. in Feby 1826—with the Bill for the erection of a National Observatory.— I took back the Volume of Congressional Documents containing my Report of Jany 1836. on Smithsonian bequest, and promised to call and see him again to converse with him on the subject— Eighth and probably last sitting to Mr Page, although the Portrait is yet far from being finished— He was unwell and worked with flagging Spirits— Mrs Robbins, wife of James M. Robbins, Representative in the General Court from Milton, came in with a Sister of Mrs Chapman; and afterwards Dr Parkman— Call at Mr Bonds shop—and he had ready for me the second Volume of “An Introduction to Practical Astronomy, containing Descriptions of The various Instruments that have been usefully employed in determining the Places of the Heavenly Bodies, with an account of the Methods of adjusting and using them— By the Revd. W. Pearson LL.D. F.R.S. &c. Rector of South Kilworth in Leicestershire, and Treasurer to the Astronomical Society of London, London— Printed for the Author, and sold by Messrs. Longman, Rees, Orme, Brown and Green. Pater-Noster Row. 1829[”]— Two large quarto Volumes with a subsidiary small volume of Plates— Mr Bond sent this second Volume, with that of the Plates to Foster’s Stable where my Horses and Carriage were put up; and Dr Parkman silently observing that there was apparently only one Volume in the package, without saying anything to me procured at the Bowditch Library, and sent for me to Foster’s stable, another second Volume, bound up with the Plates of the same work— Of which he apprized me by a note which he sent to me at Mr Abbott Lawrence’s— I met Mr Nathaniel Curtis, at the door of Charles’s Office, and gave him the Letter to the Committee of the town of Princeton, in answer to theirs proposing a bill in equity— He promised to send me a copy of our answer— I went with him and inspected the three buildings which he has caused to be erected on vacant land belonging to Mr Ward N. Boylston’s Estate—two on Faneuil Hall market Square, for warehouses, and one in the adjoining alley, for a tavern or eating house— Mr Benjamin the Architect was there— All the buildings are of brick, strong and substantial— They have taken about 300000 bricks at 6 dollars a thousand— The cost of the whole has been between 19 and 20 thousand dollars— Mr Curtis is already in Treaty for the lease of one of the Stores, and of the House in the Alley. He expects an income of 3200 dollars a year from them— At 3— I went and dined with Mr Abbott Lawrence—Mrs Lawrence the only Lady—S. T. Armstrong, P. C Brooks—(Brimmer?) S. Codman jr. Cowell—I. P. Davis, E. Everett—Finney—J. C. Gray, B. Guild, J. Heard,Longfellow—J. Palfrey—Jared Sparks, judge Story, G. Ticknor,Wadsworth, Dr Warren, John Welles and T. L Winthrop constituted the company— Mr Wadsworth reminded me that I had treated him kindly at the Hague in 1796 when I was translating Tacitus—and Mr Cowell, that he had dined with me at Ealing in 1817. withPrescott, and Prince Sanders, and recommended to him then at the University the best Edition of Cicero de Officiis—a Berlin Edition by a German Editor—all of which I had totally forgotten. Mr Cowell is now in this Country, as an Agent of the Bank of England— I Left Mr Lawrence’s table, most of the company still remaining there, before 6 and reached home about 7. in the Evening. Charles and his wife were here—
14. IV. Sunday.

No observation of the Planets— Sky-clear overhead— Thickened haze along the eastern horizon, and flitting clouds above— The Sun rose precisely at half past 6. visible from his first beam, with a crimson coloured dish well defined, and tolerable to the eye as the moon.— At Meeting, Mr Lunt preached the morning Sermon, from 1. Corinthians 10.31. [“]Whether therefore ye eat, or drink, or whatsoever ye do, do it all to the glory of God.” Less impressive than usual— Mr Whitney preached in the afternoon from John 15.22. [“]If I had not come, and spoken unto them, they had not had sin: but now they have no cloak for their sin.” Mr Whitney believes in future punishment for sin— Severe, but not eternal— His creed is the final salvation of all men.— Mr Brigham, after Meeting informed me that the School Committee would visit the town Schools next Wednesday and Friday; morning and afternoon; and invited my attendance, which I promised— I read the 11th. Sermon of the 11th. Volume of Saurin, on the two thieves crucified with Jesus— Upon death-bed conversions— Little short of 35 years since I have heard Mr M’Cormick of Washington, when Chaplain to the House of Representatives deliver in the Hall of the House, a Sermon upon this subject; much marvelling where he had found it— Some seventeen or eighteen years after, I heard him at his Navy-yard church repeat the same discourse; still ignorant whence it came— Nor did I make the discovery till this day: That it was original with M’Cormick I never could believe— The petty larceny of a Sermon, is admissible in the morals of the Episcopal church, as no violation of the 8th. commandment— Dr Parker of Boston was not so fortunate in escaping detection as Mr M’Cormick— In 1793 or 1794— He was appointed to preach before the Legislature of Massachusetts—the Election Sermon— The first time that this honour had been conferred upon an Episcopalian clergyman— He acquitted himself very creditably of the task; but immediately after the publication of the Discourse, James Winthrop, then Librarian of Harvard University, disclosed by a squib in a newspaper, that the author of Dr Parker’s Election Sermon was Saurin; a translation of some of his Sermons, having then been recently published in England; from which Dr Parker had merely copied— It was wormwood for the Doctor, to his dying day— I read also the remainder of Basnage’s History of the Jews—a refutation of certain criticisms upon his works.— He refers to the strange and distorted account of the Jewish Nation and religion in the 5th. Book of the Histories of Tacitus— I turned to it, and wished I had time to write a Dissertation upon it— Charles and his wife spent the Evening here.—
15. V. Monday.
Cloud— Fog— Steady rain— No observation of the Stars or Sun.

But at least three hours from breakfast till past noon wasted in reading Newspapers— Finished the reading of the Bible with my two Granddaughters, Maria-Louisa and Georgiana Frances— Begun 17. February 1837. It is the second reading with Mary-Louisa— The rule of reading is 4 chapters a day, and in the Psalms 5. but by means of interruptions, by my separation from them—the sickness or indisposition of either of them, and other occasional failures, the average has been about
about 2 1/4 chapters a day, or 606/1361 I read alternately with them 3 verses each in turn, with the view to teach them how to read intelligibly— I read all, suppressing nothing, passing over nothing, having no fears that their delicacy will suffer by any thing they read in that book— I think it an exceedingly mistaken roman Catholic prejudice, that any part of the Bible should be withheld from the reading of any human being who can read— The first reading of children, is like the reading of an adult, in a language which he does not understand. For intelligent reading is a double operation—the mechanical articulation of words performed by the united co operation of the organs of sight and of speech and the conveyance to the mind of the ideas signified by the words. The art of reading loud consists in performing simultaneously the three processes—the recognition of the printed or written words, the articulation of them by Speech, and the reception and conveyance to the mind and memory of the thoughts signified by the words— The ordinary teaching of children to read, is only the recognition and articulation of the words; the active operation of the mind is scarcely performed by children at all, and very imperfectly by the common mass of mankind through life.— The extreme imperfection of its performance by myself, is one of the infirmities of which I am deeply conscious, and which I never cease to lament— I answered a Letter of enquiries from Mr Charles P. Kirkland of Utica, New-York, a Candidate for election as a member of the House of Representatives of the United States for the 26th. Congress— Charles and his wife spent the Evening here.
16. V. Tuesday.
Cambridge— Exhibition— Return to Quincy.

Saw the two Planets; but the Eastern Horizon was so beclouded—that I could only see them at intervals; and it struck me as strange that Mercury appeared brighter and larger than Venus— I went in the Carriage alone to Cambridge, and as a member of the Committee of Overseers attended the exhibition, for which I received a printed circular Notification from President Quincy last week— Left home at 1/2 past 8 and reached Cambridge 1/4 past 10.— The other members of the board of overseers present were Sidney Willard, Senator from Middlesex—James G. Carter Senator from Worcester County—Governor Edward Everett, William Minot of the Council—R. C. Winthrop, Speaker of the House, Dr. Thomas Gray, and Revd. Alexander Young— Reports were read by the President, and from the Professors in the several branches of Instruction— At 11. the Exhibition commenced, and lasted about two hours— The performances were better than at the last Exhibition which I attended three years ago— There was but one deficiency of memory among the Speakers, and the elocution was good— James G. King—Brigham andHale son of a Sister of the Everetts were of the principal performers— The Attendance was thin— The Mathematical exercises creditable— I took them home with me— Governor Everett was obliged to leave before dinner—going home he told me to Newtown, and thence to Charlestown to deliver a Lecture this Evening— Mr. J. S. Buckingham the Englishman dined with us, but was obliged to leave us before the dinner was over to return to Boston, and thence this Evening to Salem to deliver a Lecture— I gave Mr William Minot, and
and the Revd. Charles W. Upham of Salem copies of my fragment Speech, but I was disappointed in failing to obtain any information whatever concerning Astronomical Observatories— Governor Everett had sent from Gottingen, a model of a moveable dome, but it has disappeared, and no one knows what has become of it— I paid a visit after dinner to Mrs Quincy, and met there the Senator Mr Carter.— I called also at Dr Waterhouse’s; but he was said not to be at home— I returned as I had gone, and reached home about 6. O’Clock.— Charles who had been this morning to Boston, and his wife spent the Evening with us— Also Mr E Price Greenleaf
17. V. Wednesday

Mr Brooks of Hingham called on me this morning, and said that Dr Matthews, Chancellor of the New-York University had proposed to put him in nomination for the professorship of natural History in that institution— He had already obtained very warm recommendations from President Quincy, and from some other gentleman, and he was very desirous of having one from me— He wanted it immediately, but I was engaged to attend the visitation by the School Committee, of the central school, at the Town Hall— He took me there. The School is kept by Jonathan French, who last year worked in my garden; but who has been liberally educated, and by a young woman named Wade Teyrld, who appeared to be the best teacher of the two— There were present about one hundred children, boys and girls, from 7 to 16 years of age, who were examined in reading, spelling, a defining recitation—geography, drawing, map-making and composition— Their writing books were also there; but were not examined; nor their cyphering— Several of them however read their own written compositions— What Mr French called their defining composition were pieces taken from their reading books, but written down in their own language varying the phrases to express the same ideas.— After an examination of about two hours, they were dismissed, a few words of exhortation having been spoken to them, by Mr Lunt, and afterwards at the request of Mr John Whitney— Mr Cornell was also there—Mr Brigham, Mr John Briesler, and several others— The examination of another School was to have been made this afternoon; but Captain Eliphalet Smith of Quincy point, died last Monday, and on account of his funeral this afternoon the further School examination was postponed till next Friday morning— I returned home to dine— Charles and his wife dined with us— As Evening approached my hoarseness, and sore throat came with increased aggravation, and I doubted much whether I should be able to go through the exercise which I had undertaken— At 7. O’Clock however I went with Charles to the City Hall; and there, for a Lecture, read the Memoir of my father’s life which I had written for Mr Herring. It occupied about 2 hours; and was listened to with great attention, by an auditory as numerous as the Hall would hold, two thirds of whom were women— The minutes of the last weeks meeting were then read; and this meeting was adjourned to this day week.— The labour of reading, and the heat of the Hall, had flushed my face and
and given me a dull head ache, with which I retired to-bed— I saw this morning the two Planets—Mercury in dazzling Splendour— The Sun rose in a clear sky at 6:34— Evening bright Northern light
18. IV:15— Thursday.

Eastern horizon beclouded—clear above— Sun rose at 6:35. but the haze at his rising point intercepted his first beam. I rose with a remnant of head ache, from the last Evening’s toil, but it dispersed after breakfast— At this Season of the year, I can seldom write in the early morning but I can read; and have begun to read Dr. Pearson’s introduction to practical Astronomy.— I shall not have time here to go through a fourth part of the Volume— From a passage in the preface I infer that the first Volume is a mere compilation of Astronomical Tables— The second Volume consists of 104 Sections— 1. Preliminary remarks, suggesting the motives and the usefulness of Astronomical Observations; an argument unnecessary for my conviction, who have never ceased throughout life to lament the narrow compass within which I have been hemmed in this pursuit §. 2— On the situation, structure and furniture of an Observatory. §. 3. Rotative dome. IV. Refracting Telescopes with celestial eye-pieces. §. 5. Diagonal eye pieces. § 6. Celestial eye pieces with variable powers. §. 7. Erect eye-pieces. § 8. A popular explanation of the achromatism of the refracting telescope. §. 9. Stands for Achromatic refracting telescopes.— Thus far I have read and now want the instruments themselves to compare with the descriptions of them, to understand perfectly their use— Minott Thayer called on me, and said they had a large meeting of the Braintree Lyceum; where they heard I was Lecturing at the Lyceum here Whereupon they chose a Committee to wait upon me and invite me to deliver a Lecture before them— I told Mr Thayer that I considered Braintree my native town as much as Quincy; and would most cheerfully read them a Lecture if it were in my power— But that I had declined at least twenty, such invitations, and among the rest one from the United Quincy and Milton Lyceum, at the Railway House— This alone compelled me to decline all similar invitations now, and all I can do now, is to make a conditional engagement for next year— Mr Thayer urged me very much, and finally disclosed the wish that I should address the Braintree Lyceum on the present state of politics, and in favour of the whighs— He is greatly concerned for the issue of the approaching election—the vibration of the popular pendulum being at this moment in full swing to the administration side— He is under great and well founded alarm for the whig candidates in this County; and their supremacy is in imminent danger throughout the Commonwealth— I see no reason however for interfering in this Election, the turn of which depends almost entirely upon, a License Law enacted last Winter, prohibiting the sale of spirituous liquors in quantities less than 15 Gallons—a well intended, but indiscreet Law which has thrown the whole Commonwealth into a Convulsion— Mrs Lawrence came here again with the Military Land-warrant, issued in the name of her late husband Jonathan
Jonathan Lawrence, which she wishes me to sell for her— But the land is in the State of Missouri, and has been sold for taxes she knows not to whom; nor when; nor for what price—nor who is its present possesor— Doctor Shurtleff has made enquiries for her heretofore, through an agent in Missouri named Harrison— But her husband died 25. September 1825. leaving an only Son named James Monroe Lawrence, born in Novr. 1816. and now of age— And one question is what portion of the remnant of the right to the land goes to the son, and what to the mother— I advised Mrs Lawrence to obtain a written statement of all these facts, and furnish me with it together with the Land warrant, before I go on to Washington, which she said she would do— The three Mrs Adams’s took tea and spent the Evening at Mrs T. B. Adams’s— Mrs Smith has been three days confined to her chamber. The children Maria Louisa and Georgiana Frances had their tea at home, and I played Lotto with them, and sung French Songs to them— I then wrote an hour, and shortly before 9 walked to Mrs T. B. Adams’s, and soon with Charles, back.
19. V: Friday.

Rain—Morning—Noon and Night— Reading §. 9. Stands for Achromatic refracting Telescopes— What a world of ingenuity has been expended upon contrivances for facilitating Astronomical observations by the Telescope. There seems to have been no discovery of the Laws of the Universe since Newton— The more recent discoveries are of facts— New Planets— Additional Stars and new phenomena brought within the compass of human vision— The improvement in the mechanism of the Instruments and the use of Logarithms for calculations— Dr Charles W. Windship called again this morning for my declaration that his father Dr. Amos Windship was a Surgeon of the Frigate Alliance in 1779 and 1780—which I had ready drawn up for him— I returned to him the papers that he had left here; but he said he wished to keep my declaration, and that I would be sworn to it before a magistrate; which I promised to do— I attended the visitiation of the South School, near the house formerly William Baxter’s. Mr Lunt, Captain John Whitney and Mr Brigham, Mr Savil of the Farms were there—and others were there— The School is kept only by a man, Mr Cumings—about 100 Scholars male and female are in attendance from 7. to 16 years of age— Reading, writing, spelling, parsing, grammar, mental arithmetical computation, geography, without map-drawing, composition, and speaking were the exercises in which the children are examined— The reading was without drawling or cant, but without emphasis, monotonous, and with little apparent intelligence of what was read— Many of the children had bad coughs, which occasioned much interruption of noise and some confusion— After the examination was over the children were briefly addressed by Mr Lunt and afterwards by me. Mr Noah Curtis, who belongs to this school District expressed some dissatisfaction that the use of Slates and of practice of the rules of Arithmetic in writing is abandoned, and the children are taught only to add, subtract, multiply and divide, memoriter, which he said could be practiced only for small sums— It rained copiously; and Mr Savil of the farms took me home in his Chaise— Immediately after dinner I rode to the Farms School-house, which is on the western side of the road to Neponset Bridge, about half a mile this side—kept only by a young woman named Campbell— The number of children attending
attending at this school is from 35 to 40, but the weather being bad there were not more than 30 present— Mr Lunt was not there; nor any member of the School-committee, except Captain John Whitney the Chairman.— The proficiency of the Children was far inferior to that of either of the other schools—but their behaviour was equally good— My address to them was of course very brief— I got home shortly before Sunset— The printer’s boy of the Quincy Patriot, brought me the proof of the second half of my list of Anti-Texas and abolition petitioners; which I revised for publication in the paper of to-morrow— And I continued writing till near the close of the Evening.
20. V. Saturday.

Rain ceased soon after Midnight— Morning cloudy— Clear after Sunrise. No observation— §. 10. Equatorial or Parallactic stands— Last Tuesday the 16th. I began the reading with my Grandchildren of the French Bible of Silvestre de Saci— My purpose is to combine lessons of reading of the French language and of the bible, in one exercise— For this purpose I make each of them in turn read one chapter of the French Bible by three verses at a time— The other reading also by three verses at a time the same chapter, in the English version; and then I make the reader of the French translate the principal words into English— We thus read only one chapter a day, and it will take four years, should my life and health and theirs be so long spared to go through the Bible in this manner— The result is with him who works in us to will and to do— My wife, with Mrs Smith, Mary and Abby went to Boston, and returned to dinner— I walked to the Germantown School-house, which has recently been removed, and rebuilt nearer to that village— Mr Lunt and Captain Whitney were there, with a Mr Brown, and another whom I did not know— The School is kept by a very handsome young woman from Cape Cod, named Atkins— But she has been there only three or four months, and the pupils are less advanced than even those at the farms— The numbers usually attending at this school are from 30 to 35—but there were now present only ten boys and nine girls. After the examination Mr Lunt addressed them and I followed him— He took me as far as the Meeting house homeward whence I walked home After dinner, I should have planted nuts and seeds and Acorns, and visited for the purpose my Garden, Nursery and Seminary; but they looked so desolate and the weather was so chilly that I did nothing— Went to Charles’s House to see the Sunset, and borrowed my Spy-glass. Miss Torrey was there— Charles’s eldest son John has been ill—confined two or three days to the house; but is recovering— Charles and his wife spent the Evening here— Michael Quinlan the young Irishman who has lived with us as a house waiter, left us this morning, and I gave him a certificate of good conduct—
21. V. Sunday.—

I have been watching several days to observe the rising of Arcturus having perceived by the direction of the Stars Benetnach, Mizar and Alioth, in the tail of the great where it must be— This morning I saw him very distinctly about five minutes, risen, a quarter past five— He rises North, not much of the range of the Zodiac— I think Mercury has disappeared, and that the brilliant Planet which I saw this morning was Venus, rapidly approaching to the Sun— Mr Muzzy of Cambridgeport was our preacher
preacher this day in the place of Mr Lunt— His morning Sermon was from Matthew 24.35. [“]Heaven and Earth shall pass away, but my words shall not pass away.” A strong argument for the perpetual existence of Christianity— In the afternoon his text was Mark 9.23. [“]Jesus saith unto him, if thou canst believe, all things are possible for him that believeth.”—on the omnipotence of Faith— I have an earnest desire to write a discourse or Lecture upon that subject; but fear I shall never find the time— Mr Muzzy’s argument, forcible and earnest, considered Faith, as synonymous with belief—and such is the definition of Saint Paul, when he says it is the substance of things hoped for—the Evidence of things not seen— The passage in the text makes all things possible to belief—but Faith in what? belief in what? Belief in God, and his moral attributes— Belief in the immortality of the Soul, and the responsibility of a future State— Belief in the Lord Jesus Christ, and in his doctrines— This is the belief or Faith which is to ensure Salvation— But mere belief is a passive condition of the mind—not altogether voluntary— A man cannot always believe what he wishes— Even the belief in the existence of God, he cannot command— Further, Faith while merely identical with belief, is barren, and produces no fruits— Faith in numberless passages of Scripture is an active principle— It is fidelity— It is the invariable principle of fulfilment of promise— It is in this sense that God is said to be faithful— He promises and performs— Now the performance of promise essentially belongs to immortality— No other being upon earth, but man, can make a promise, or in other words can pledge his faith— No other animal can receive or trust in a promise— And this capacity to promise and to believe is the foundation of all human Society The matrimonial union is entirely founded on a mutual pledge of faith— The aggregation of men in a community, has no other foundation than a mutual pledge of faith— And faith can be preserved only by mutual fidelity— The breach of faith on one side dissolves the bond of Union, and henceforth no Social ties can remain between the parties— Mr Muzzy dined with us, as did Mr Degrand who came out from Boston—and spent the day with us— Charles and his wife were here in the Evening; and Mr Beale and his daughter Ann— From ten in the morning till ten at Night I was without five minutes of time my own— So that I lost the reading of a Sermon of Saurin, which I was obliged to postpone till to-morrow Morning.
22. IV:45 Monday

Beclouded morning and no observation— I began the day by reading the 12th. and last Sermon of the 11th. volume of Saurin, upon the last words of Jesus Christ to Mary and to St. John—a very remarkable discourse which I should be glad to read again—as I would indeed the whole of this Volume of Sermons upon the Passion— There are some very curious statements concerning the Roman Catholic worship of the Virgin Mary, and of the legend of Saint Bridget concerning the festival of the sworn to commemorate the alleged fainting fit of Mary at the Crucifixion of her Son— The divine honours that have
have been paid to Mary, are among the most nauseous corruptions of Christianity; and stagger all confidence in the sanity of the human intellect— Mr Wild of Braintree, who calls himself Parson Wild was here; and had with him a letter to the Fence viewers of Quincy, signed by B. V. French and Caleb Hollis, and which he said French had requested him to sign—but he had no wish to make the fence nor wish to have a misunderstanding with any one— Nor did he think it right that he should pay for the service of the Fence Viewers— He finally concluded that he would not sign the paper, but would make his fence if Mr French should make his, to which I told him I had no sort of objection— But he wished to shorten his fence by taking a small corner of my land into his; and to this I declined consenting— My wife with her two daughters, Mary and Abby went to Hingham, and visited the Misses Thaxter— I wrote to Miss Anna Quincy Thaxter, and sent her a copy of my fragment Speech, and of my Address of 18. August last to my Constituents of 18. August last— Garden— I sowed a second row of 12 Shagbarks, 12. English white Oak Acorns—Ash-seeds, Peach-stones, Apples and Pear Cores and seeds from the shed where the tools are kept to the garden gate next the kitchen— Charles and his wife spent the Evening with us— I read the introduction, and first chapter of Dick’s Celestial Scenery
23. IV:30. Tuesday 23

The first clear morning sky for many days. When I came in to my Chamber I found Venus risen about a quarter of an hour.— About a quarter of an hour after I saw Arcturus just risen, and a quarter of an hour later Mercury blazed with dazzling brightness, and surpassing in size the most brilliant effulgence of Venus— He remained visible 20 minutes after the disappearance of Venus and Arcturus, and within 20 minutes of the rising of the Sun at 6.42— I have read in Pearson’s introduction to Practical Astronomy §. 11. The construction and use of the Dynameter—an instrument for measuring the magnifying power of different Telescopes, said to be important, to be known by the observer. § 12. The Dorpat refracting Telescope, said to be the most expensive on, ever constructed—made in 1825. by Fraunhofer of Munich, for the use of the observatory of the imperial University of Dorpat— Sold by Utzschneider for 10500 florins about 4750 dollars— See and remember the Memoirs of the Astronomical Society of London— §. 12. On reflecting Telescopes— I endeavour to read one section every morning; but see I can effect nothing without much more time than it is possible for me to bestow upon this subject.— Mr Minott Thayer with three other persons came as a Committee from the Caucus Meeting at Braintree, to invite me to address the inhabitants of Braintree on the political Aspects of the Country— Mr. Hollingsworth explained what had been left somewhat indefinite by Mr Thayer. He said the first proposition made had been to invite me to deliver a Lyceum Lecture, which had been changed, to that of calling on me to speak to a political meeting on political subjects—this was a contrivance of Minott Thayer, to coax me into an electioneering whig Speech— I told them that as to the Lyceum Lecture, I considered
considered Braintree as much my native town as Quincy— I had declined every invitation to deliver Lyceum Lectures this Season, with the single exception of Quincy, of whose Lyceum I am myself a member, and to which I made a conditional engagement to that effect last year— I would make the same engagement for the Lyceum of Braintree for the next year, if my health should permit— But, as to addressing the People of Braintree upon the political Aspects of the Country, there were other difficulties, which I ought in candour to state to them— The subjects of political dissensions were changing in this Country.— Texas, the War with Mexico, were no longer to be dreaded; nor I hope debated— The right of petition may again be outraged; but I could say no more on that subject at this time— The Sub-Treasury had been swelled up by both parties from a Molehill into a Mountain— I did not believe it would again be pressed at the next Session; but if it should, and should be carried it would infallibly demolish the Administration of Mr Van Buren— But the question of Slavery would come up in a great variety of forms and upon that subject I was not sure that my opinions would concur with those of the whigs of Braintree— I enlarged upon this for more than I can now record. But I said the division of parties now turned upon the act of the Legislature of the Commonwealth, passed at their last Session commonly called the License Law, upon which I had not made up my own mind— They asked if I thought it unconstitutional— I said so far as I had seen and considered it, I thought not, but, I must say, I regretted that it had been passed— Thayer said there were such a multitude of petitioners, and no opposition, that the General Court could have done no otherwise than as they did— Finally I said to them that as to addressing the Inhabitants of the Town of Braintree, on the political aspects of the Country; it was to be considered whether by setting the example of doing it in one town, I should virtually pledge myself to do the same if desired to every town in the District— It would immediately change the mode of elections here, to the stump eloquence of the Southern and Western States, which would be a very pernicious alteration for this part of the Country.— They appeared to think this reasonable—thanked me for this interview, and retired— Mary and Abby were going to Weymouth, and I rode with them to the School at Quincy-Point, kept by George Newcome— I arrived late and much of the examination was already passed. The examination in Geography in Arithmetic in Grammar and composition was continued and concluded— They answered all the questions of the Teacher, in the words of the book, by heart; but they had no equal dexterity to answer questions very apposite to the examination, but not in the books— The compositions were few and not equal to those of the central school; but there was here what I have not seen at any of the other school a printed return of the number of scholars attending at the school, which is 66—average number 57. There were this day 59.—boys 33. girls 26. Mr Lunt addressed them after the close of the examination and I followed him— The carriage with
with the Ladies, returned from Weymouth was waiting for me, at the door, and I rode with them home— Charles went to Boston, and returned to dine— He and his wife dined and spent the Evening with us.— After dinner, Mrs Smith, with Mary and Abby rode to Milton, and took me with them to the western or railway school, the sixth and last town school at the examination of which I have attended—kept by a young man named Babcock— I was again late— But the examination was a very bad one— Mr Lunt declined to address the Scholars— Captain John Whitney Chairman of the School Committee did address them, and told them that the examination had not been satisfactory— That their reading was bad—their writing not good, and that they seemed unable even to repeat, and still more to understand their lessons— I followed him and said I had been a very unwilling witness of the correctness of his remark— I hoped and believed they would all feel themselves spurred to overtake the children of the other Schools— I said there was one exception to the bad examination— It was a girl of about 16. who promptly answered almost every question— Mr Marsh a member of the Committee succeeded me, and said there was an excuse for their deficiency at this time as they had not enjoyed the same advantages as the Children at the other Schools; but warned them, as they did now enjoy the same advantages, it would be expected that they would exhibit corresponding improvement, at the next quarterly examination— The number of scholars attending at this school is about 80.—but there were present only 54 boys 29. girls 25. I walked home, with Mr Lunt— We had a take leave visit from Mr Peter Whitney.— Evening hand at whist.
24. IV:15. Wednesday

Rain morning, noon and evening, and consequent confinement, to the House.— Having at the request of the School-committee of the town of Quincy attended the examinations of the Scholars at the six public town-schools, many reflections have occurred to me in desultory and confused order which I have not time to digest— By the Laws of the Commonwealth, School returns are since 1833, made yearly from every town in the State— Those from Quincy for 1834. of children from 4 to 16 years of age attending School were 312 male 295 female = 607. average attendance 452. Male and female teachers each 6.— Amount raised by tax for the support of Schools 2000 dollars— For 1835— Attendance of Children 336 Males 330 females— Average attendance 500. Male teachers 6. female 7. Tax raised 2000 dollars— Scholars at private schools 90.— For 1836. The children between 4 and 16 years of age belonging to the town are returned 704.—all, that is 356 males and 348. females attending the Schools— Average attendance 463— Teachers 6. Males and 7 females.— Amount raised by taxation 2000 dollars—private school pupils 110.—paid for their schooling 750 dollars.— The return for 1837. Is in different form, and with columns of statement somewhat different— Population of the town 3049. Valuation 528.891.25. Children between 4. and 16, 724. Attending School 345 in Winter 450 in Summer. Teachers
Teachers in Summer 3 Males 6 females, in Winter 6. Males no females— Tax raised 2275 dollars—private Scholars 75— Tuition paid for them 900 dollars— It is evident that these returns have been made by different persons, and with different principles of computation— At this examination of all the Schools, I found the whole number said to be attending at all the Schools was 451—present at the examinations 344—not one half of 724— Male teachers 4. female 3. falling short of all the recorded returns.— The modes of instruction of the different teachers are not uniform, and the female teachers struck me as superior to the males. There is a great multiplicity of books—different at different Schools— The discipline was well observed on the whole, but not equally in all the Schools— The returns for the present year, Mr Lunt informs me are not to be made till next Spring— Would it were in my power to do good in this matter.— Read in Pearson §. 14. Stands for reflecting Telescopes, and 15. The Herschellian forty-feet Telescope; with a list of Herschel’s papers in the Transactions of the Royal Society from 1780 to 1818. and §. 16. Herschelian Telescope, as constructed by Ramage— The want of the Instruments to compare with the descriptions leaves three fourths of what I read unintelligible; and the Algebra takes off half of the remainder— The weather was so bad that Charles and his wife could not come this Evening— I read a couple of Chapters in Dick’s Celestial Scenery— Still harping upon Astronomy— In these occupations and amusements time flies like light.
25. IV. Thursday

This was the day upon which my wife had fixed for her departure with the family, for Washington; but although the rain had held up in the Night the weather was not promising this morning, and she concluded to postpone her departure till next Monday— I read in Pearson’s Astronomy §. 17. On the space-penetrating powers of Telescopes; which Sir William Herschel discovered to be very different from the magnifying power, and which seems to depend upon the contrivance of devices to increase the quantity of light within the tube.— The book says that the naked eye can discern no star in the heavens of less than the 7th. magnitude, but I never could perceive any of less than the 5th. §. 18 An historical account of the different methods of measuring small celestial Arcs— This Section is introductory to a series to Section 45. on micrometers and micrometrical instruments; covering nearly 200 pages of this quarto Volume upon this little appendage to the Telescope a micrometer— I sent a note and box to Mary by her two children; and after long delays wrote in half a page for the Executors of Ward N. Boylston, a Letter to Petty Vaughan declaring our acceptance of the proposal in his Letter ofSeptember 1836 to Joshua Bates— I began also a Letter in answer to one received from Isaac L. Hedge, Seth Sprague junr. and Elihu Hobart, Committee of the whig Convention, held at Halifax on the 16th. instt. to nominate a Candidate for election to represent the 12th. Congressional District of Massachusetts in the House of Representatives, for the 26th
26th. Congress, informing me that the nomination had been unanimous of me— To my answer of acceptance I think it proper to add some observations; but did not finish them— Mr Price Greenleaf was here this afternoon, and I walked with him round upon Mr Daniel Greenleaf’s farm; returning over the Bridge of the bathing wharf.— Charles and his wife spent the Evening with us.
26. IV:15. Friday.

The morning was crystal clear— I Saw Venus rise at half past 4— Arcturus at 5. Mercury at 40 minutes past 5. and the Sun at 46. minutes past 6.— Mercury was much the brightest of the Stars, and was visible till within 20 minutes of the rising of the Sun— My thermometer 5. minutes before sunrise was in the open air at 34.— I read in Pearson §. 19. on the Spider’s line Micrometer of Troughton’s invention and § 20. Other methods of determining the value of a Micrometer’s screw—in which title the word value has a technical and astronomical, and not a pecuniary meaning— There is in this Section Algebra to make it unintelligible, and Tables for consultation and not for reading— We had sundry visitors this day—of whom Mr Fletcher and Mr Tarbell, from Boston— Fletcher has been nominated by the whigs, for reelection to the House of Representatives of the United States, at which he is naturally much gratified— He engaged me to dine with him next Tuesday. Mrs Lloyd, whom I think I had not seen since the death of her husband was here with Mrs S. B. Barrell— Mrs Lloyd is one of my cotemporaries— I knew her as Hannah Breck in 1785. She is of course now verging towards 70— She has lived her whole life in affluence, and is now very wealthy; but has an air of gravity, chilling cold and solitary— Her father in 1792 removed to Philadelphia, to escape from Boston taxation— Many years after, Her husband who had represented Boston in the Senate of the State and in H.R.US. and by the favour of Boston the Commonwealth in the Senate of the United States, repeatedly resigned without apparent adequate motive these offices, and finally removed to Philadelphia, for change, and finally died at New-York— He made a princely fortune, by commerce, and doubled it by speculative purchases of land in the State of New-York—died childless, leaving an Estate of at least eight hundred thousand dollars to be scattered among collaterals, without a dollar of bequest, in charity, or to any public use— Fortune, and Ambition showered their favours upon him, in unremitting profusion— Thrifty, prosperous, opulent, popular, he was always restless and discontented—died unlamented, and is forgotten— The key to all which is that he was of a Tory breed; lived an old bachelor till he married to a barren bed, and was therefore denied the blessing of a child; and was by nature of a fretful, peevish temper. He was a very intelligent merchant, but carried too much of the counting house into the Legislative Hall, to be an eminent Statesman— He was my classmate at the University, and always as much my friend as comported with his own interest— His widow with
with feelings more true to nature, than those of her husband or of her father, has returned to spend her last days at the place of her nativity— Mrs Miller and her daughter visited our ladies.— That family has just removed to Boston, for the winter— I dined at my Son’s in company with Mr Lunt— Conversation with him upon the condition of the Town Schools, and upon the various meanings of the words Faith in the Scriptures— While I was out after dinner, Mr Haskell, a clerk in one of the public offices at Washington, with a Mr Brainard of Boston, were here; and also, Mr T. Loring of Hingham, with Miss Anna Quincy Thaxter, who came to ask my consent to the publication of my last Letter to her— Charles and Abby spent the Evening here—
27. IV:10. Saturday.

My Granddaughter, Mary-Louisa, was seized before midnight with violent cramps, and sickness at the Stomach, which kept her mother up with her, nearly the whole Night, and my wife a considerable part of it— She was convalescent, but confined to the chamber all this day.— I saw this morning the two planets and Arcturus and the Sun at rising—but all much intercepted by Clouds. Thermometer before Sunrise at 36. I read in Pearson §. 21. Micrometrical scale with a constant magnifying power—and §. 22. On the different methods of illuminating the Lines, in the eye-piece of a Telescope—such as Dr Usher’s lamp; Dollond’s lantern—Fraunhofer’s Lamp—Tulley’s Illuminator &c— The theory of the Universe has been discovered by observation of the Stars—and the glass-grinder, has accomplished nearly as much in the cultivation of this Science as the observertor of the skies.— Optics, Catoptrics, Dioptrics, Algebra, trigonometry, the Construction of Logarithims, Mensuration of heights and distances, and keen eyed, learned instrument-makers, are all essential to the Science of Astronomy— Morning visit from Mr Lunt, who was going to preach to-morrow at Plymouth. Also from Mr Catlin, the collector and owner of the Indian Gallery, last Spring at Washington and now at Boston; with Mr Gregory the Mayor of Jersey City and his two sons, boys of 10 and 12 years of age; and of Mr Ellis, also of Jersey City, who brought with him, two copies of the Memoirs of General La Fayette published by his family; one of them bound, to be presented by me to the Congress of the United States; and one, unbound—for myself, with a kind and affectionate Letter from George Washington La Fayette—the General’s Son— Mrs Smith, Mary and Charles’s wife went into Boston, and returned to dine, in a heavy thunder storm, and floods of rain— Charles went also to Boston, and returned home to dinner. Dr Duggan was here and called me out from dinner, with a petition to Congress from several inhabitants of Quincy that a Pension may be granted to Mrswho was married the 14th. of Jany 1794—only 14 days after the time limited by the act of Congress of the last Session— The Doctor was very courteous— I told him there must be a petition from the widow herself; which he said he would take care to procure— Charles spent the Evening here; but his wife fatigued with her trip to Boston could not come
28. IV.30 Sunday
