The Morning was clear— On coming into my library I found Venus, less than 5 minutes risen— Arcturus rose 7 minutes before 5— I went over to Charles’s house to see Mercury rise at 5:48. and the Sun rose as nearly as I could observe in my chamber at 6:49. The Thermometer in the open air was at the freezing point, and Mercury was dis-tinctly visible 45 minutes— Of course till within 15 minutes of Sunrise.— Mr Briggs, settled since the 2d. day of last January at Plymouth as Colleague to Dr Kendall preached here this morning from Matthew 9:6.—“Our father, which art in Heaven.”— The whole discourse was an amplification of one idea, that the peculiar exellence of the Christian religion consists in the character attributed by Jesus Christ, to God—as the father of all mankind— A good sermon, well delivered, with some unacceptable peculiarities of pronunciation— There is no doubt something exceedingly attractive in the paternal relation which Jesus always considers as existing between God and man— Yet as a religious doctrine, it must be understood as a mere figure of Speech— The relation of God to man, is that of a Creator and Creature— That of father and Son is physical, terresterial—mortal— It is full of tenderness and affection; but perishable, and implies in its literal sense a Mother— An implication which in the History of Christianity has produced enormous mischief both of practice and opinion— The word father in the figurative and spiritual Sense is altogether indefinite— Jesus Christ himself is often termed the only begotten son of God, and in one of the Psalms, quoted and applied to Jesus by Saint Paul, God says this day have I begotten thee— The paternity of God to man is therefore different from the paternity of God to Christ; nor does it constitute the essence of Christianity. It is remarkable that the Pagans of antiquity attributed this character of Father to Jupiter, the most powerful, and to Bacchus the most sensual of their Gods— Mr Briggs, who told me he was born at Little Compton, Rhode-Island, dined with us, and preached after dinner from Matthew 15.6. “Thus have ye made the commandment of God, of none effect, by your tradition”— Against traditional authority— Sensible and judicious— It clouded up in the course of the morning; rained all the afternoon; and as evening came on turned to Snow, which continued some hours till the ground was covered— I read the first Sermon of the 12th. and last Volume of Saurin—on the substitution of Jesus Christ for the victims of the Levitical Law.— The text is Hebrews 10.5.6.7. a quotation by St. Paul from Psalm 40.6. according to the Greek Septuagint—with a remarkable variation, in the Hebrew Bible, which reads thoug hast bored my ears; alluding to Exodus 21.6. The Septuagint have it thou hast given me a body— Saurin explains all this as well as he can.— Other perplexing difficulties he leaves without solution— I had read this morning in Pearson § 23 A new polymetric reticle, an instrument of his own invention; otherwise called Pearson’s Crystal Micrometer—and § 24. Reticulated Diaphragms; which Section I did not get entirely through— Charles and his wife spent the Evening here, spite of the Snow.
29. IV: Monday

Partially clear Morning— Saw the two Planets, Arcturus and Sunrise following in their order— Arcturus rising each day 4 minutes sooner than the day before; and Mercury later, visibly approaching every day nearer to the Sun.— I read in Pearson §. 25. Circular and annular micrometers, and §. 26. La Caille’s method of registering and reducing
-cing the observations made with his reticles.— Observation, calculation, registration—three distinct operations, all essential to the Astronomer, and for all which he should be qualified— I read with my two Grandchildren Mary Louisa and Georgiana Frances, the 13th. chapter of Genesis in the French Bible of Sacy— My wife, Mary and her two Children, Thomas the Coachman, and Margaret the Lady’s maid, with Mrs W. S. Smith and her black maid Charlotte Dorsey departed at 1/2 past 1. P.M. in Gillett’s Stage for Boston, where at 3. They took the Cars of the Rail-road to Stonington; for New-York, where they are to leave Mrs Smith with her husband, and proceed to Washington— Charles went with them to Boston and immediately returned.— He and his wife spent the Evening here.— I had a morning visit from Coll. Arthur P. Hayne of South-Carolina, with Isaac P. Davis— Coll Hayne is brother of Robert Y. Hayne, sometime Governor of South-Carolina, and long a Senator of the United States— Some years since Coll. Hayne went to England— At the request of the late Commodore Rodgers, I gave him a Letter to the Duke of Sussex who treated him very kindly— The Colonel, a man of great solemnity of forms, is grateful in his way and gave me a pamphlet extracted from Herring’s gallery of American Portraits, being a biographical notice of himself, written, he said by his brother
30. IV. Tuesday
Boston—dinner at T. Tarbell’s with R Fletcher— Quincy.

Last night was clear, calm and cold; whence we hope the family had an easy passage from Stonington to New-York— This morning I saw Venus, Arcturus, Mercury and the Sun successively rise— The daily changes in their time of rising, and in the relative declination of the Sun, Venus and Mercury, are very curious— On the 4th. of this Month at 5. A.M. Venus and Mercury were in close conjunction; on the 6th. they were yet nearer, and rose about 4:45. Arcturus was not yet visible, and the Sun rose at 6:18. On the 21st. I first saw Arcturus, which then rose 10 minutes past 5— Venus has been approaching to the Sun, but Mercury, parting daily more distant from her; and constantly approaching the Sun. On the 26th. Venus rose at half past 4. Arcturus at 4:50. Mercury at 52 minutes past 5. and the Sun at 51 minutes past 6— I read in Pearson §. 27. Smeaton’s method of using a wire Micrometer with an equatorial stand—with tables— Then Double image micrometers. §. 28. Dollond’s object glass micrometer applied to a reflecting Telescope— I went into Boston with Charles and his wife, who took with her their Son John— We left her at her sister Frothingham’s— I called on Mr George Bancroft, and had a long conversation with him upon historical topics, and the biography of my father— Bancroft is preparing a second volume of his History of the United States; and was very inquisitive of anecdotes relating to my father’s life.— He returned to me C. F. Mercer’s Report of 18. March 1836. on the National Observatory, which I had lent him; and said that he had written to Mr O’Sullivan upon the subject of the Observatory, and hoped to engage the aid of Mr Gilpin to the cause— He said also that he had thoughts shortly after the commencement of the approaching Session of Congress to make a short visit with his wife, at Washington— He is lately married to his second wife— I next visited Governor Edward Everett, who has just returned to the City from his Summer residence at Watertown— Conversation with him, upon the action of the Legislature of the Commonwealth within the last four years for the improvement
-provement of common Schools— As Governor of the Commonwealth, he is Chairman of the Board of Education, and takes great interest in the success of the efforts now making to raise the standard of Education in the State— The institution of the Normal Schools is now the labouring point of this system, and its most formidable difficulty, is the necessary increase of expense to carry it into execution.— The Spirit of the Towns, is parsimonious— The increase of the School tax will not easily be carried, and if the Legislature should make it imperative, a reaction like that now operating against the License-law would ensue— I also conversed much with him, upon the disposal of the Smithsonian bequest fund— I told him what had passed between President Van Buren and me on this subject; and of my own wishes with regard to the preservation and appropriation of the fund— He assented to the justice of my principles, and strongly expressed the hope that my purpose may be carried into effect— He promised me a copy of his Letter to professor Farrow, from Göttingen, on the subject of an Observatory and suggested several points worthy of deliberate consideration; among which was that of having two Astronomers attached to the Observatory— One as Observer, and the other for the calculations; which he says is the principle of the establishment at Göttingen.— I asked him, who, he thought would be the most suitable person for observing Astronomer.— He named several persons, distinguished in the pursuit of mathematical and astronomical studies, and appeared to give the preference to professor Olmstead of Yale College— I requested Mr Everett to write to me on the subject, and to give any suggestion that might occur to him for the promotion of the cause— The morning was consumed, by these two visits so that I could make no more— After 2 I called at Charles’s Office, and then at his house where I found him, and Painters and white washers, preparing the house for habitation— Went with him to Mrs Frothingham’s, where we remained till 4. O’Clock— Then we went and dined with Mr Fletcher; at Mr Thomas Tarbell’s in Avon Place.— A small party—Judge John Davis, Governor Edward Everett, Revd. Mr. Gannett Professor Simon Greenleaf, Mr Hale, Judge Story, and Mr Wooster of Cambridge, with Mr Fletcher and Mr Tarbell, Charles and myself constituted the company. Judge Story was as eloquent as usual— At 7. we returned to Mrs Frothingham’s, took up Abby and her son, and returned home to Quincy.— We came in as the Clock struck 8. chilled through and through— Charles and his wife went immediately home—
31— IV. Wednesday.

I had an almost sleepless Night— Heard the Midnight Clock, and between one and two was awakened by sharp cramps in the calf of my right leg, which forced me out of my bed, but immediately subsided— I laid however till 4. meditating this as an admonition, and considering how easily such a turn in my solitude might take me to my account without further notice— And in fervent prayer, that I may be duly prepared for such a visitation, and a spirit of humility to meet it— I then rose, and in going out found the snow falling, and a white sheet already upon the ground— Of course no sight of Stars— After making my fire washing face, hands, feet and mouth with cold water, I found I could not write— Read Pearson §. 29. Experimental Determination of the focal length and errors of a divided Object-lens, used with a Gregorian Reflector
Reflector; and §. 30. Dollond’s improved Object-glass Micrometer— I read over again also the documents of J. F. Mercer’s Report of 18. March 1826. in favour of a National Observatory. The further I proceed in the consideration of this subject, the more I feel the want of more mature judgment and more minute knowledge— Alpheus Spear was here, with a minute from Lewis Bass Chairman of the Select men, of the town and County tax on the Mount Wollaston farm for the last 3. years— It was 31. for 1836— 37: for 1837. and 38 for 1838. nearly double the estimate upon which we had agreed and for which he had paid me— But he said he was not satisfied with it; and wished to enquire further concerning it— He was going to Dedham, upon his lawsuit, with Mr Cummings the teacher of the central school, who refused to receive and teach his children. He recovered a verdict against the master at the Court of Common Pleas— There was an appeal to the Supreme Court, where it is made a question of Law, and is to be argued this day or to-morrow— Deacon William Spear was afterwards here, and told me the point of Law in the case of Alpheus’s suit.— In Districting the town for Schools, the old Mount Wollaston house was included in the Germantown District.— The new house built perhaps 30. feet west of it, Alpheus considered as within the centre District, and he sent his children to the centre school, where the master refused to instruct them— The Deacon had much more discourse with me on political topics, and particularly on the license law, which is about to revolutionize the State into a Van Buren Colony— The Snow continued all the morning; and cleared off in the afternoon cold— Charles, and his wife and three children dined here His wife returned with them to her own house after tea; but Charles spent the Evening with me—

Day. The changes of the Seasons occasion involuntary changes in my occupations.— I cannot as the winter’s cold comes on, sit down to writing, as the first business of the day. I can only read; and during the latter half of this month, I have read every morning, after rising between 4 and 5, till breakfast time between 8 and 9.— Then the mail of Letters and newspapers employs me till noon, or an hour later— Dinner comes between 2 and 3—with my Diary running in arrear, and correspondence much neglected— After dinner a walk or ride, and more rarely an hour of writing.— The Sun sets now at 7 minutes past 5—and thenceforward, the society of my family is my pastime till 10 at Night, about which time I retire to bed.
